content.text: Achieving sustainable development requires policies that are not only well-designed within individual sectors but also harmonized across multiple areas to prevent conflicts and maximize synergies. Policy coherence ensures that economic, social, environmental, and governance policies work together toward common objectives, particularly in the energy transition. Without deliberate alignment, policies in one sector can undermine progress in another, leading to inefficiencies and missed opportunities.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: What is policy Coherence?

content.text: Policy coherence refers to the systematic alignment and integration of policies across various sectors to achieve consistent and mutually reinforcing outcomes. It involves ensuring that policies in different areas—such as economic, social, environmental, and governance—work together harmoniously, minimizing conflicts and maximizing synergies. This approach aims to prevent situations where a policy in one sector undermines the objectives of another, thereby enhancing the overall effectiveness and efficiency of policy interventions.

Policy coherence in the context of sustainable energy or energy transition refers to the deliberate alignment and integration of policies across various sectors to ensure that efforts to promote sustainable energy are consistent, mutually reinforcing, and free from contradictions. This approach aims to systematically reduce conflicts and promote synergies between and within different policy areas to achieve the outcomes associated with jointly agreed policy objectives

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Pillars of policy coherence?

content.text: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has outlined four pillars to enhance Policy Coherence for Sustainable Development (PCSD): Pillar 1: Institutional Capacity and Skills, Pillar 2: Country practices and support Pillar 3: Analysis and data Pillar 4: Partnerships and peer-learning

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | A
content.title: A. Institutional Capacity and Skills,

content.text: This pillar emphasizes strengthening the abilities of institutions and individuals to design and implement coherent policies aligned with sustainable development goals. It involves building competencies within public administrations to manage complex policy interactions effectively

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | B
content.title: B. Balancing Affordability and Sufficiency

content.text: This pillar focuses on sharing best practices among countries and providing support to integrate policy coherence into national strategies. It aims to facilitate mutual learning and tailor support to specific country contexts, enhancing the implementation of coherent policies.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | B
content.title: C. Analysis and data

content.text: This pillar emphasizes strengthening the abilities of institutions and individuals to design and implement coherent policies aligned with sustainable development goals. It involves building competencies within public administrations to manage complex policy interactions effectively

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | B
content.title: D. Partnerships and peer-learning

content.text: This pillar highlights the importance of multi-stakeholder partnerships and peer-learning mechanisms. Engaging various stakeholders, including civil society, the private sector, and academia, fosters inclusive policy-making processes and promotes the exchange of knowledge and experiences.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Mechanisms to measure and enhance policy coherence

content.text: The UN Environment Programme has proposed a set of mechanisms to measure and enhance policy coherence, with a focus on promoting policy coherence for sustainable development. key components include:

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | A
content.title: A. Institutionalization of political commitment

content.text: Institutionalization of political commitment is likely to promote policy coherence for sustainable development by instilling a culture of policy coherence and guiding action towards it at all levels of government. Political commitment at the highest political level, as an initial step, is likely to trigger the establishment and/or the enhancement of other mechanisms that enhance policy coherence for sustainable development.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | B
content.title: B. Long-term considerations in decision-making,

content.text: Long-term considerations in decision-making, through mechanisms which ensure that decision-making, policy development and planning follow objectives that are long term (i.e., span beyond the current electoral cycle and consider the interests of future generations). This mechanism ensures that decisions are informed by long-term effects and perspectives, rather than only focusing on short term gains or issues.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | C
content.title: C. Inter-ministerial And Cross-Sectoral Coordination

content.text: Coordination of inter-ministerial and cross-sectoral promotes policy coherence by linking relevant ministries and agencies through a central coordination body. This ensures alignment, reduces overlaps, and allows for periodic review of sectoral impacts and trade-offs. In cases of political opposition, fragmented decision-making can lead to delays and corruption risks. Strengthening formal coordination enhances transparency and improves policy effectiveness.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | D
content.title: D. Participatory processes

content.text: Participatory processes that go beyond a “whole-of-government” approach and integrate relevant stakeholders from the “whole-of society” in a comprehensive manner. This allows for the engagement and integration of the concerns expressed by relevant stakeholders potentially affected or having an interest in energy governance.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | E
content.title: E. Developing policy linkages

content.text: Developing policy linkages to guarantee coherence and assess policy affects and cross-sectoral linkages throughout the policy and planning processes. This ensures that policies across sectors are pursued in a balanced way that avoids competition or overlap between instruments, institutions, and sectors. Mechanisms for assessing policy effects and cross-sectoral linkages should allow to ensure that potential negative impacts are prevented and mitigated, and potential positive synergies optimized, and thus that policies in different sectors are coherent amongst themselves. Conversely, without adequate collaboration, opportunities to harness positive cross-sectoral linkages may be missed. Further, such mechanisms would ensure that cross-cutting issues, such as gender or health, are mainstreamed into all sectoral policies.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | F
content.title: F. Alignment across government levels

content.text: Alignment across government levels to ensure that policies, plans, and programs at all levels of government (national and sub-national) are aligned and mutually supportive, and do not contradict or work against each other.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | G
content.title: G. Monitoring and Reporting

content.text: Monitoring and reporting for policy coherence involve regularly evaluating the effects of policies on various dimensions of sustainable development and cross-sectoral impacts using specific indicators. These evaluations should inform adaptive actions to ensure policies remain aligned and effectively address sustainable development goals.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | H
content.title: H. Financing for policy coherence

content.text: Financing for policy coherence promotes the alignment of private and public finance to policy coherence objectives while tracking related expenditures. This ensures that funds from different sources are coherent with national policies and priorities.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | I
content.title: I. Administrative capacity

content.text: Although not part pf the framework by the UNEP, building administrative capacity is another vital mechanism for policy coherence in sustainable development. Weak institutional frameworks, especially at the local level, can hinder energy sector reforms and policy implementation, particularly in vertically integrated utilities facing financial strain. Strengthening capacity through training and technical support ensures more effective policy execution and greater alignment in energy transitions, overcoming obstacles to sustainable governance.

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

cards.title: Policy coherence ensures that policies across different sectors align to achieve sustainable and mutually reinforcing outcomes. By minimizing contradictions and maximizing synergies, policy coherence strengthens governance efficiency and prevents fragmented decision-making that could undermine sustainability objectives.

Strengthening institutional capacity and stakeholder engagement is essential for achieving policy coherence in energy governance. Enhancing skills, fostering multi-stakeholder partnerships, and integrating participatory processes ensure that policies are well-coordinated across government levels and responsive to societal needs.

Mechanisms such as inter-ministerial coordination, policy linkages, and long-term planning enhance policy coherence for sustainable development. Institutionalizing political commitment, improving monitoring frameworks, and aligning financial strategies help maintain coherence across policies, ensuring a just and effective energy transition.
